awd_titl_txt: Dynamical Systems in Quantum Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The subject of this project is quantum information theory, which is a crucial ingredient for the development of meaningful quantum technologies. Quantum devices use quantum systems, such as electrons, atoms, photons, to encode and process information. They make it possible to harness the effects of purely quantum phenomena such as superposition (the ability of being in "two places" at once) and entanglement (extremely strong connections between two, often quite remote, parts of the system) in order to drastically increase the security and speed of computational devices such as quantum computer. While entanglement became one of the most valuable resources in quantum theory, many of its attributes remain unknown. At present, one of the main technological challenges in quantum information arises from the destructive effects of environment, the effect known as decoherence. Decoherence is a partial loss of quantum information through a channel, in other words, the introduction of noise into the communication. This project will contribute to understanding how these losses may be theoretically predicted and minimized. Students at different levels will be trained through participation in this project. Another educational objective of the project is to promote STEM subjects and improve educational opportunities for students in Houston, TX, middle and high schools, with?main focus on economically disadvantaged neighborhoods.

Two, often overlapping, research directions will be pursued in this project: quantum information theoretic inequalities and dynamics of quantum systems. Quantum information theoretic inequalities, such as monotonicity of quantum relative entropy and strong subadditivity of entropy, are at the core of providing a framework for what is theoretically possible to achieve in quantum information. Dynamics of open quantum systems describing the effects of the environment is notoriously challenging and vital problem.  The principal goals of the project are: (i) to improve understanding of the role of entropy in the quantum setting through a sharpening of the monotonicity of different relative entropies as well as the formulation/derivation of quantum versions of classical information-theoretic inequalities; and (ii) to rigorously describe attributes of quantum entanglement by seeking upper bounds for the speed of generation of entanglement. This investigation is largely motivated by the need to understand and control the decoherence in quantum channels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum information theory aims to harness purely quantum phenomena, such as superposition and entanglement, in order to improve and secure communication, increase computation and communication speed, reduce storage requirements and complete other information processing tasks that classical computers can never achieve. This project has advanced the mathematical side of quantum information theory by addressing several problems in quantum dynamics by investigating applications of quantum quasi-relative entropy.

Quantum quasi-relative entropy is a measure of distinguishability between two quantum states. The most important property of this quasi-relative entropy is that it does not increase when the states pass through a noisy quantum channel, making it harder to distinguish these quantum states. This property is called the Data Processing Inequality. This project has provided an error bound on the decrease of the quasi-relative entropy in very simple terms, a long sought-after estimation. This result has already generated several citations and further work in the quantum information theory community. Quasi-relative entropy is not the only type of relative entropy, and this project has investigated the data processing inequality for another large class of relative entropies, called quantum alpha-z Renyi relative entropy. The saturation (equality) in the data processing inequality was investigated, as well as the convexity (and its stability) of several related operator trace functionals.

Quasi-relative entropy was also used as a distance measure to find the closest separable state to any pure entangled state. Entangled states are purely quantum, while separable states can be viewed as almost classical states, making them easier to work with in quantum computation. The problem of finding the closes separable state to any (not necessarily pure) entangled state is still open even for the most basic quantum relative entropy. This project has proudly contributed to the advancement of this long standing problem.

Several other problems were successfully addressed in this proposal, such as the entanglement rate for various entanglement measures. In other words, how fast the entanglement changed in time, when it is measured by different entanglement measures. Different relative entropies were taken to construct quantum coherence, discord and other quantum correlations measures.

This project has supported the training of one graduate student, who was awarded a prestigious postdoctoral position after graduation. Moreover, this project supported a mathematical instruction that goes beyond regular school curriculum for several dozen middle-school children from underserved neighborhoods. These children successfully learned subjects that are often taught in college, such as probability, graph theory, combinatorics, math logic, and others. But most importantly, these extra-curricular activities helped children to visualize themselves in college as STEM majors, which is often difficult to do for students from underserved neighborhoods. This project served a big role of empowering children to attend and graduate from college, and to choose STEM as a major.
